pull.title: [Fix] Allow connection of a noban banned peer
pull.body:
Reported by @MarcoFalke on https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16248#discussion_r314026195

The bug would mean that if the peer connecting to you is banned, but whitelisted without specific permissions, it would not be able to connect to the node.

The solution is just to move the same line below.

events.body: Is this safe to do? What are the implications of connecting to a peer that would otherwise be banned?

@gapeman afaik that was the behavior before #16248 (which was not supposed to change existing behavior).

@NicolasDorier would be nice to have a test for this.
I refactored it to properly scope some variables. Writing a test so such regression can't happen.

verification.payload:
tree aab9946044dae6258d1e82c6cf8c945679a90951
parent 8fc7f0cba9b1b60ce25d6a8ba51052af1461f825
author nicolas.dorier <nicolas.dorier@gmail.com> 1565854492 +0900
committer nicolas.dorier <nicolas.dorier@gmail.com> 1565876432 +0900

[Fix] Allow connection of a noban banned peer

events.message: [Fix] Allow connection of a noban banned peer

events.body: Fixed the bug, and added an anti regression test for `setban`
Travis failed due to lint issue. Maybe rename `rpc_setban.py` to `p2p_whitelist.py`?

As @promag suggested, I instead just inlined the permission checked, it is actually more readable.

I also check in the logs that we really prevent connection because of the ban. I also added a test to `setban x remove`.
@Sjors `rpc_setban` is the right name, I really want to test setban, so I added it in the whitelist of authorized term.

comments.body:
test/functional/rpc_setban.py:7:1: F401 'test_framework.test_node.ErrorMatch' imported but unused

test/functional/rpc_setban.py:39:78: F821 undefined name 'p'

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,44 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env python3
+# Copyright (c) 2015-2019 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+"""Test the setban rpc call."""
+
+from test_framework.test_node import ErrorMatch
+from test_framework.test_framework import BitcoinTestFramework
+from test_framework.util import (
+    assert_equal,
+    connect_nodes
+)
+
+class SetBanTests(BitcoinTestFramework):
+    def set_test_params(self):
+        self.num_nodes = 2
+        self.setup_clean_chain = True
+        self.extra_args = [[],[]]
+
+    def run_test(self):
+        # Node 0 connects to Node 1
+        self.assert_has_permission('noban', False)
+        # Node 0 get banned by Node 1
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        # Node 1 should not be able to reconnect
+        self.restart_node(1, [])
+        connect_nodes(self.nodes[0], 1)
+        peerinfo = self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()
+        assert_equal(0, len(peerinfo))
+        # Node 1 should be able to reconnect if it has noban permission
+        self.restart_node(1, ['-whitelist=127.0.0.1'])
+        connect_nodes(self.nodes[0], 1)
+        self.assert_has_permission('noban', True)
+
+    def assert_has_permission(self, permission, contains):
comments.body: Maybe pass node in directly and split into `assert_has_permission(self, node, permission)` and `assert_has_no_permission(self, node, permission)`

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,44 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env python3
+# Copyright (c) 2015-2019 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+"""Test the setban rpc call."""
+
+from test_framework.test_node import ErrorMatch
+from test_framework.test_framework import BitcoinTestFramework
+from test_framework.util import (
+    assert_equal,
+    connect_nodes
+)
+
+class SetBanTests(BitcoinTestFramework):
+    def set_test_params(self):
+        self.num_nodes = 2
+        self.setup_clean_chain = True
+        self.extra_args = [[],[]]
+
+    def run_test(self):
+        # Node 0 connects to Node 1
+        self.assert_has_permission('noban', False)
+        # Node 0 get banned by Node 1
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        # Node 1 should not be able to reconnect
+        self.restart_node(1, [])
+        connect_nodes(self.nodes[0], 1)
+        peerinfo = self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()
+        assert_equal(0, len(peerinfo))
+        # Node 1 should be able to reconnect if it has noban permission
+        self.restart_node(1, ['-whitelist=127.0.0.1'])
+        connect_nodes(self.nodes[0], 1)
+        self.assert_has_permission('noban', True)
+
+    def assert_has_permission(self, permission, contains):
comments.body:
what about `assert_equal(True, self.hasPermision(...))` ?

That said, I don't think it should pass the nodes to this method. It is confusing (there is two nodes: the node that is permissioned, and the node on which we want to check permissions).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,44 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env python3
+# Copyright (c) 2015-2019 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+"""Test the setban rpc call."""
+
+from test_framework.test_node import ErrorMatch
+from test_framework.test_framework import BitcoinTestFramework
+from test_framework.util import (
+    assert_equal,
+    connect_nodes
+)
+
+class SetBanTests(BitcoinTestFramework):
+    def set_test_params(self):
+        self.num_nodes = 2
+        self.setup_clean_chain = True
+        self.extra_args = [[],[]]
+
+    def run_test(self):
+        # Node 0 connects to Node 1
+        self.assert_has_permission('noban', False)
+        # Node 0 get banned by Node 1
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        # Node 1 should not be able to reconnect
+        self.restart_node(1, [])
+        connect_nodes(self.nodes[0], 1)
+        peerinfo = self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()
+        assert_equal(0, len(peerinfo))
+        # Node 1 should be able to reconnect if it has noban permission
+        self.restart_node(1, ['-whitelist=127.0.0.1'])
+        connect_nodes(self.nodes[0], 1)
+        self.assert_has_permission('noban', True)
+
+    def assert_has_permission(self, permission, contains):
comments.body:
`assert(self.hasPermision(...))` is even simpler.

You could pass both nodes. Or you could document at the top of the test file which hardcoded nodes do what.

+# Copyright (c) 2015-2019 The Bitcoin Core developers

comments.body: Sorry but I think you could just inline this - it's longer as it is with the `contains` arg.
